title: Chalfont St Giles Walking Route

images.title: Chalfont St Giles: Captain Cook Monument and Moat by Nigel Cox, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Captain Cook Monument and Moat. The Vache is an estate near the village. Located within the estate is a monument dedicated to the memory of Captain James Cook (1728–1779), the explorer.

images.title: Chalfont St Giles: View northward from the Captain Cook Monument by Nigel Cox, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: View northward from the Captain Cook Monument

images.title: River Misbourne by michael, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: River Misbourne

images.title: MortimerCat, CC BY-SA 3.0 <http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Milton's Cottage in the village. In 1665 Milton and his wife moved into the cottage to escape the Plague in London. While at the Grade I listed cottage, he completed his best known work, Paradise Lost; the seeds for Paradise Regained were also sown here. The 16th century timber framed cottage is now a museum. The four museum rooms contain the most extensive collection in the world on open display of 17th-century first editions of John Milton's works, both poetry and prose. Tours vividly describe and explore the extraordinary career of this blind genius in his refuge from the plague, where he wrote some of the finest poetry.

images.title: Timo Newton-Syms from Helsinki, Finland & Maidenhead, Berkshire, UK, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Church view. Magnolia trees are in full bloom in the churchyard.

description: This pretty Buckinghamshire village sits in a nice rural spot on the edge of the Chilterns AONB. The village is part of the 'Chalfonts' along with Chalfont St Peter and Little Chalfont. The worthy settlement includes a picturesque village green and a duck pond fed by the River Misbourne. Other highlights include the church of Saint Giles which is of Norman architecture and dates from the 12th century. The village is also notable as the former home of John Milton, author of the epic poem 'Paradise Lost'. Milton's cottage is now a open to the public as a museum and includes an extensive collection of 17th-century first editions of John Milton's works, both poetry and prose. This circular walk from the village uses a section of the South Bucks Way to take you along the River Misbourne to the neighbouring town of Amersham. The route then takes you to Coleshill village before heading to Hodgemoor Woods where there are some pleasant woodland trails to try.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: Merlin's Cave is a good choice for some post walk refreshments. The pub serves good food and has a nice garden area. You can find them on the village green at postcode HP8 4QF for your sat navs.

details.subtitle: Dog Walking
details.content: The country and woodland trails are ideal for dog walking. Merlin's Cave pub mentioned above is also dog friendly.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: The sister village of Chalfont St Peter is located just to the south east. Near the village you will find a historic highlight of the area at the Chiltern Open Air Museum. The museum rescues and restores common English buildings from the Chilterns and relocates them to its 45-acre site, which includes woodland and parkland walking trails. For more walking ideas in the area see the Chilterns Walks page.

display_address: Crown Barn, Up Corner, Chalfont St Giles, Denham, Gerrards Cross and Chalfonts Community Board, Buckinghamshire, England, HP8 4PY, United Kingdom
